Itâ€™s not as strong as the case from the heart, admittedly, but itâ€™s there. Thereâ€™s no denying an element of Tobias Funke â€œbut it might work for usâ€ to it all. Yet itâ€™s hardly damp-eyed delusion to look at Conte and Pochettino and conclude that both men are probably better suited to the otherâ€™s job. And even then, wanting to stick with Conte is a perfectly viable position that it should be entirely possible for Spurs fans or anyone else to hold without having to denigrate what Pochettino achieved and could still offer. At the very, very least, Pochettinoâ€™s likely availability and keenness given the closing-off of alternative avenues offers the security of a better and cheaper back-up option than Spurs could realistically hope for should Conteâ€™s wandering eye take him elsewhere.

Content_title: Levy left â€˜irritatedâ€™ by Conte reports as Tottenham plan to â€˜block out noiseâ€™
Contents: Daniel Levy is â€˜irritatedâ€™ by reports linking Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte with a summer move to French giants PSG. The former Chelsea boss replaced Nuno Espirito Santo at Spurs back in November. Tottenhamâ€™s fortunes have improved since Conte took over. He has won 17 of his 31 games in charge across all competitions. Is Pochettino a better manager for Spurs than Conte? Spurs are in the running for a Champions League place. They are two points behind fourth-placed Arsenal with five games to go. It was reported earlier this week that Conte has â€˜offered himselfâ€™ to PSG. The Ligue 1 side are currently managed by former Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino. The Argentinian is under pressure at the moment. PSG are 13 points clear at the top of Ligue 1 but they were dumped out of the Champions League by Real Madrid. The Athletic have noted that reports linking Conte with PSG have â€˜irritatedâ€™ Levy. Tottenham experienced a similar â€˜distractionâ€™ in 2020/21 when Harry Kane announced that he wanted to leave before the season concluded. They add: â€˜There is generally a desire at the club to block out the noise and get on with it. â€˜There is also an acceptance that volatility is part of the package when you appoint Conte, and that the focus has to be on the team overcoming their recent blip and qualifying for the Champions League. Itâ€™s also inevitable that when you have one of the gameâ€™s elite managers, they will be linked with other clubs â€” especially when you are not in the Champions League yourselves. â€˜That said, there are some who feel Conte has hardly dampened speculation over the last couple of months, given the way in which heâ€™s refused to talk about his future at Spurs beyond the immediate term. â€˜As for the players, with no midweek fixture they were given pre-arranged days off on Sunday and Monday, and are not expected to have been too affected by the reports. â€˜In general, Conte is very popular with the players, though there have been times, most notably after the post-Burnley meltdown in February, where they have been unsettled by the up-and-down nature of their head coachâ€™s mood.â€™

Content_title: Juan Mata shows Man United what theyâ€™ve wasted in beautiful Old Trafford swansong
Contents: Juan Mata came, he conquered, and was forgotten about. The â€˜Wizardâ€™sâ€™ last home game for Manchester United emphasised his misspent quality. For Manchester United â€“ a club in turmoil, in need of calm heads, desperate for humility amid the arrogance, quality amid the mediocre â€“ to hand Juan Mata his first Premier League start of the season in May is an absolute nonsense. The â€˜Wizardâ€™, denied legendary status in the Premier League through Red Devil mismanagement and ill-thought-out strategy, trotted around Old Trafford on Monday, working hard, creating and â€“ perhaps most importantly â€“ caring, to give the United fans a final glimpse of what they should have seen far more of in seven-and-a-half years of wasted talent. Mata arrived at the club having won back-to-back player of the year awards with Chelsea, as one of the Premier Leagueâ€™s foremost creators. He contributed the same number of assists (32) in two-and-half seasons at Chelsea as he has in the rest of his decade-long stint in the English top flight. He very nearly surpassed his Chelsea tally on Monday. It was prime Mata. Having wandered over to the left wing from his floating No.10 role, he beautifully cushioned a volley to Bruno Fernandes on halfway, beat the offside trap to spin in behind, received the return ball, before weighting a cross perfectly into Cristiano Ronaldoâ€™s path. Had CR7 held his run by half a second, Mataâ€™s brilliance would not have been in vain. And that is, in a way, an excellent summary of his United career, as Ronaldo â€“ like his club â€“ failed to take advantage of Mataâ€™s quality. As Gary Neville referenced on commentary, the signing of Mata in January 2014 is in hindsight seen as the first of many signs of post-Fergie fuzzy-thinking. Having signed Marouane Fellaini six months before, David Moyes opted for the polar opposite as his second and final signing. Neither the Belgian brute nor the diminutive graduate of the Real Madrid academy were midfielders like any other in the preceding 20 years at Old Trafford, and have since been deemed unsuited to the hustle and bustle â€˜attack, attack, attackâ€™ of United. That speaks to perhaps the biggest problem at United in Mataâ€™s time at the club â€“ the obsession to cling to the coattails of Sir Alex Ferguson and maintain a style of football theyâ€™ve never got close to matching. Mata, and many signings since, havenâ€™t been a good fit for that United, but maybe, just maybe, itâ€™s the attempted style thatâ€™s been the greatest hindrance to the clubâ€™s progress, rather than the undoubtedly talented footballers that have failed to reach the heights they scaled at other clubs. Having said that, this victory over Brentford, Mataâ€™s only start of the season, which admittedly felt a bit like a testimonial, was as close to a Sir Alex Ferguson-like performance as any weâ€™ve seen this term. They broke quickly, with Mata, Fernandes and Ronaldo laying balls off smartly, accurately and running beyond each other. It was â€“ and this hasnâ€™t been the case for far too long â€“ entertaining football. And entertainment has been the name of Juan Mataâ€™s game in the Premier League. Heâ€™s put smiles on the faces of fans and teammates alike with unlikely assists, delicate touches and stunning long-range strikes. But most of those fond memories came in Chelsea blue, before a United career blighted by managers who failed to appreciate what he could do if they used him effectively. He leaves the Premier League with his head held high but with an irrefutable sense offrustration at what could have been.

Content_title: Liverpool are â€˜seriously interestedâ€™ in bringing PL star to Anfield
Contents: Liverpool are keen to bring West Ham forward Jarrod Bowen to Anfield in the summer transfer window, according to reports. The 25-year-old has made 31 starts this campaign and has found the back of the net 12 times whilst providing nine assists. He has been hotly tipped to receive an England call-up amid his terrific form, with the next international break taking place in late March. Liverpool have Salah situation wrong and Leeds fans want more Liverpool were rumoured to be interested in the Hammers man earlier in the season but now his form has only served to increase their desire to bring Bowen to Anfield in the summer. GiveMeSport transfer insider Dean Jones has claimed: â€˜Maybe Jarrod Bowen is next on their radar and heâ€™s somebody theyâ€™re seriously interested in.â€™ The Reds reinforced their forward line in January when they invested Â£37m on Luis Diaz, with the fee potentially reaching Â£49m if the winger triggers certain add-ons. Liverpool are trying to tie Mo Salah down to a new contract with the Egyptianâ€™s deal expiring in the summer of 2023. There have been rumours that the Reds will attempt to bring the average age of their frontline down further and now Bowen could be their main summer target after he â€˜caught the attention of Jurgen Kloppâ€™s sideâ€™. Meanwhile, John Barnes doubts Bowen would ever be able to replace Salah but the former Liverpool midfielder doesnâ€™t doubt the West Ham playerâ€™s class. â€œJarrod Bowen is playing for a team that are in the top four or five in the Premier League, so heâ€™s playing at the very top â€“ as of right now,â€ Barnes toldBonusCodeBets. â€œHe needs time to develop; heâ€™s in his first real season playing for a better side. â€œBowenâ€™s never going to sign for Liverpool and replace Mohamed Salah. He is a different type of player to Mo, he isnâ€™t going to score 30 goals a season, thatâ€™s not what Jarrod Bowen does. â€œIn terms of his talent, can he play at big top five club? Absolutely.â€ Joe Cole was waxing lyrical about Bowen after their recent draw against Newcastle with the former West Ham midfielder claiming the 25-year-old is â€œgetting better and betterâ€. Cole said on BT Sport: â€œHeâ€™s unbelievable, every time I watch him Iâ€™ve been so impressed with him. Heâ€™s getting better and better and better. Heâ€™s movement is so good. Heâ€™s a lovely deliverer of set pieces as a well. Heâ€™s one of the most improved players in the league.â€

Content_title: Who thinks the Manchester United Treble beats a Liverpool Quadruple?
Contents: Stan Collymore, thatâ€™s who, though we think itâ€™s largely because Stan Collymore was playing in 1999. Hit Quad Mediawatch had to check that Stan Collymore is actually only 51 after reading his latest â€˜it were better in the olden daysâ€™ column in the Daily Mirror. His contention is that actually, Liverpool winning the Quadruple â€“ literally never achieved before in football â€“ would not be that impressive in the grand scheme of things. Of course, it would be a â€˜fantastic achievementâ€™ but â€˜it wonâ€™t be any greater than Tottenhamâ€™s Double in 1960-61, Arsenalâ€™s in 1970-71, or Liverpoolâ€™s in 1985-86â€™. Weâ€™re fascinated to hear how four trophies are actually no better than two, apart from â€˜because it were better in the olden daysâ€™. Weâ€™re fascinated to hear how Arsenalâ€™s 1970-71 side â€“ who crashed out of the League Cup and Europe â€“ are actually the equal of a team that wins all four trophies available at a time when they are up against the greatest club side of the last decade. Weâ€™re fascinated to hear how Liverpoolâ€™s 1985/86 side â€“ barred from Europe but beaten by mid-table QPR in the League Cup â€“are actually the equal of a team that wins all four trophies available at a time when they are up against the greatest club side of the last decade. And then comes â€˜Manchester Unitedâ€™s Treble in 1998-99 which, pound for pound, would still be the greatest achievement of allâ€™. Why? Even the staunchest United fan would have to agree that four is a bigger number than three. United won the title with 79 points, a total surpassed by Liverpool and Manchester City this season with several games to spare. They also won the FA Cup and the Champions League but they lost in the third round of the League Cup. And yet that is still the better achievement than winning all four trophies? Because everything was better when Stan was playing? Collymore offers literally no explanation why United winning three trophies is better than Liverpool potentially winning four, other than a lack of â€˜financial dopingâ€™, which kind of ignores two things: 1) United spent rather a lot of money to win those trophies and 2) The â€˜financial dopingâ€™ of Manchester City, United and Chelsea in modern times makes it even more remarkable if Liverpool win four trophies. He then writes that when he played, â€˜Matt Le Tissier spent his career with the Saints, but heâ€™d have been taken on by one of the big boys after a couple of years these daysâ€™, to which we offer the words â€˜Harryâ€™ and â€˜Kaneâ€™. We could also point out that Le Tissier turned down several moves away from Southampton but actually, we have already given that argument more credence than it deserves. â€˜Spurs, Arsenal and Kenny Dalglishâ€™s Liverpool all hit the heights with smaller squads than Jurgen Kloppâ€™s Reds and City have at their disposal todayâ€™. They hit smaller heights with smaller squads at a time when all their rivals had smaller squads too; Spurs played 49 games to win their double and Liverpool have played 56 games already. Youâ€™re comparing apples with oranges and deciding that pineapples are better.  Done Ron Ron Ron â€˜At least you can rely on Cristiano Ronaldo to lift the spirits,â€™ writes Neil Custis in The Sun. â€˜A sparkling display, capped by his 24th goal of the season from the penalty spot, gave Manchester United fans something to cheer. In fact, he has probably given them the only things to cheer this season.â€™ Is this the same Ronaldo and indeed the same Neil Custis that collided to bring us these words in February? â€˜The truth that is now staring everyone in the face, and clearly Ronaldo himself, is that his days as a top-class footballer are over. â€˜It has been an admirable battle against father time but he is now losing it.â€™ â€˜Losing itâ€™ and yet now, less than three months later (and three months older for Ronaldo), â€˜they need him still, even at 37, as they look to the futureâ€™. But, but, butâ€¦ â€˜The problem, though, is that when the ball is at his feet, or on his head, there is no magic any more, it has all gone.â€™ Itâ€™s almost like â€“ and stop me if this is blowing your minds â€“ Ronaldo had a blip in form at the same time as Manchester United were utterly atrocious and he is now neither completely finished nor the future for United. But why acknowledge middle ground when you can lurch wildly between extremes? Somebody give Custis one of those heated lavender packs to treat his whiplash.   Fergie timeHeadline on The Sun website as Ken Lawrence writes about â€“ and we had to check this â€“ a 3-0 victory: â€˜Man Utd verdict: Final home game played against backdrop of depression and disillusion, itâ€™s a far cry from Fergie daysâ€™ Itâ€™s been nine f***ing years; get over it. â€˜For the last home match of the season came agains the backdrop of depression and disillusion at a club that under Sir Alex Ferguson ruled the Premier League and on a couple of occasions did so in Europe too. â€˜This is a very different United to the one Fergie guided to 13 titles, two Champions League successes and so much more silver wear.â€™ â€˜Silver wearâ€™ has made us laugh at least (itâ€™s the pick of about 427 mistakes, including a description of Ronaldo as a â€˜waining starâ€™ and a brief discussion of â€˜parametresâ€™), but the rest of this is utterly miserable. It is a â€˜very different Unitedâ€™ but how many times can that be written? Thousands, it seems. Manchester United have not had a very good season, but a 3-0 win over Brentford gave Lawrence the chance to write about the farewell of Juan Mata or maybe the promise of Anthony Elanga. That he watched that victory and essentially wrote â€˜this Manchester United is not as good as Fergieâ€™s Manchester Unitedâ€™ says a great deal about tabloid journalism and its obsession with a past in which they were still relevant.  Do one, Ron, RonKen Lawrence on The Sun website: â€˜Ronaldo does not fit those parametres no matter that he had a sparkle about him against Brentford in what was his best all â€“ round performance in months. â€˜And in those months there have been hints for months that without Champions League football next season he will head off. â€˜He certainly wonâ€™t want to be involved in the Europa League or perish the thought, playing in Europeâ€™s third tier Conference.â€™ Ken Lawrence on the back page of The Sun: â€˜CRISTIANO RONALDO dropped his biggest hint yet that he wants to stay at Manchester United â€“ after mouthing: Iâ€™m not finished.â€™ That all seems perfectly clear.  Down, down, deeper and downElsewhere in Stan Collymore land, he seems to think that Burnleyâ€™s survival absolutely would not reflect badly on the recently sacked Sean Dyche, in fact â€˜the opposite because every player at Turf Moor is a Dyche playerâ€™, and yet Leedsâ€™ relegation would be down to â€˜the over-egging of the Marcelo Bielsa puddingâ€™. Now try and hold both of those opinions at the same time without getting a throbbing headache.

Content_title: Neville details what Ten Hag needs to achieve in the next five years at Man Utd
Contents: Gary Neville insists that Erik ten Hag should be expected to win the Premier League title in the fourth year of his reign at Man Utd. The Dutchman was confirmed as the new permanent Red Devils boss last month with interim manager Ralf Rangnick making way at the end of the season. Man Utd beat Brentford 3-0 on Monday night to move six points ahead of seventh-placed West Ham â€“ who have a game in hand on Rangnickâ€™s men â€“ but itâ€™s unlikely that that the Red Devils will now finish higher than sixth position. Manchester United are shuffling their pack, but can lost leopards change their spots? Ten Hag has a huge job on his hands to get Man Utd competing for Premier League titles again and Neville has set out his timeline of expectations for the Dutchman. Neville said on Sky Sports: â€œI said four to five years to win a title and I donâ€™t disagree with Jamieâ€™s timeline of Champions League in the first two seasons while heâ€™s sorting the recruitment out and getting used to the club. â€œThird season getting very close, I think to the point whereby the club have got confidence and won a trophy maybe. â€œAnd then that fourth year really is where they have to win a title, fifth year. Thatâ€™s where I think really youâ€™re looking at the moment realistically. â€œWe all hope he comes in and blows everyone away and that Jurgen Klopp and Pep Guardiola blow up somehow. â€œBut theyâ€™re not blowing up are they? Theyâ€™re achieving the same numbers of points year in year out so if their consistency remains, which thereâ€™s no reason to say it wonâ€™t then Ten Hagâ€™s got a massive job to make up that points gap.â€ Year 1-2 | #UCL qualification Year 3 | Title challengers Year 4-5 | Premier League Winners ğŸ† Gary Neville lays out the timeline that he expects Erik ten Hag to achieve things at Manchester United. pic.twitter.com/yd4KtSvhgc â€” Football Daily (@footballdaily) May 2, 2022 Fellow pundit Roy Keane thinks the main thing Man Utd need to improve on is their recruitment with a lack of the right characters in the Old Trafford dressing room. â€œWhatever their problems, they have to look at where Man City are, where Liverpool are,â€ Keane added. â€œMan City, Liverpool and these other teams arenâ€™t going to take it easy over the summer. Theyâ€™re going to reinvest, get players in and get stronger. â€œKlopp might stay on, Pep might stay on. It comes down to recruitment: getting the right players in and getting players out of the door, because the last few years just havenâ€™t been good enough. â€œHow many times can you say it? The biggest frustration for me, when theyâ€™ve had these disappointments, is the reaction theyâ€™ve shown. Thereâ€™s been a real lack of leadership, not enough characters in that dressing room.â€

Content_title: Manchester United are shuffling their pack, but can lost leopards change their spots?
Contents: Manchester United are switching their senior management about, but will United supporters get the transfer guru that theyâ€™ve craved for years? Manchester United reach the end of the 2021/22 season in a state of flux. Theyâ€™ve played 22 games in all competitions since the start of this calendar year and theyâ€™ve won just eight of them, with only three of those wins having come in the last two months. At the start of the year, the club had three easily identifiable aims for the second half of this season: the FA Cup, the Champions League and qualifying for next yearâ€™s Champions League. But four months into the new year, and regardless of a stroll-a-thon win against a Brentford side that didnâ€™t seem to want to push them too hard, any optimistic predictions for the end of this season now lie in tatters. Juan Mata shows Man United what theyâ€™ve wasted in beautiful Old Trafford swansong United were eliminated by Middlesbrough in the FA Cup and Atletico Madrid in the Champions League, while their involvement in the race for fourth place in the Premier League may still be mathematically possible in theory but would depend on such an improbable sequence of results that itâ€™s fair to completely disregard their chances as anything other than fanciful. The potential for a break in the clouds hovering over Old Trafford comes in the form of new manager Erik Ten Hag, who will take control of the team this summer, but the carousel of accusation has long left behind the notion that the fortunes of a football club in the modern era can be changed for the better by the appointment of one person. The problems at Manchester United run deeper than just the manager, and it was never very likely that the appointment of a new one would cure what ails the club. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer wasnâ€™t the only member of the Manchester United management team to leave their position last year. Ed Woodward had to (eventually) fall on his sword over his involvement in the European Super League fiasco, though he didnâ€™t leave his position until the start of February, and now Matt Judge, whoâ€™d previously been described as Woodwardâ€™s â€˜right handâ€™, has resigned from his position as Manchester Unitedâ€™s director of football negotiations. This follows the decision of the club to appoint Richard Arnold as the new chief executive in January and then John Murtough as director of football in February. Judge, who is currently working out his notice period with the club, will not be missed by the clubâ€™s supporters. As the man responsible for negotiating transfers and contracts for Manchester United, Judge became one of the most influential people working behind the scenes at Old Trafford, but after what has come to be considered transfer failure after transfer failure, United fans seem pretty much agreed that just about anybody would be better. Woodward and Judge were, after all, the pair who came up with the wheeze of extending player contracts as a way of maintaining asset value on business spreadsheets, which many believe has been a key reason behind the United squad becoming so unbalanced, while reaffirming to critics the fundamental differences between running Manchester United for the benefit of the stock market over just getting on with being, well, a football club.  It has been suggested that the reason for Judgeâ€™s departure at this time is related to Murtough being promoted over his head and cutting off his direct contact with Arnold, though it should be added that most of this does at least seem to be passing fairly amicably, which in itself might be considered somewhat surprising when we recall the extent of the factionalisation of the United dressing room and the steady torrent of leaks that has been flowing from behind those doors over the course of this season. United supporters certainly seem to know who they want to replace him; Paul Mitchell has been earning admiring glances for years. After moving from Southampton to Spurs with Mauricio Pochettino in 2014, he left White Hart Lane two years later to work first with RB Leipzig and then with Monaco as a sporting director in a position that he has held since 2020; Newcastle were said to be considering his services at the end of last year before settling on Dan Ashworth instead, a decision which isnâ€™t exactly going as Newcastle might have hoped. Mitchell is understood to have a close relationship with Ralf Rangnick from his time in Leipzig. He was constantly linked with a move to Old Trafford when the club didnâ€™t even have a sporting director, and now that Murtough is in that position â€“ with Darren Fletcher as technical director â€“ the fans are clamouring for him to be offered Judgeâ€™s old position. After all, Judge isnâ€™t the only person from this side of the club to have left his position in the last few months; chief scout Jim Lawlor and head of global scouting Marcel Bout have also departed. But this might not be straightforward. The Mirror has reported that, â€˜The Englishman [Mitchell] has been tempted to stay by the offer of a sizeable budget to spend at Monaco in the upcoming windowâ€™, based on reporting in Foot Mercato, which claims that Chelsea are also interested in his services. There is also little to suggest that Mitchell is unhappy in Monaco, while others might argue that, although his record with Spurs â€“ where he was behind the decisions to take Dele Alli, Son Heung-min and Toby Alderweireld to the club â€“ was excellent, his record at Monaco has not quite left him above criticism. And as ever with Manchester United, all of this raises as many questions as it answers. If Murtough and Fletcher are now running the clubâ€™s recruitment, where would Mitchell fit into the equation? If Darren Fletcher is a â€˜technical directorâ€™, then what is he doing in the dugout on a Saturday afternoon? What exactly is his role? Because even his own attempts to clarify it havenâ€™t exactly sounded convincing. But those questions will keep coming. How do Manchester United plan to attract the elite-level players to which they believe themselves to be entitled if they canâ€™t offer Champions League football? Where does Ralf Rangnick fit into all of this, especially considering that he will now be mixing his consultancy duties with being the head coach of the Austrian national team? Can any new structure or head coach change the culture of leaking to the press which has been relentless this season from a hopelessly factionalised dressing room? And ultimately, will Joel Glazer still be having the final say on all of these changes? Time is of the essence.Itâ€™s not that long until the end of the season and the reopening of the transfer window, and few would argue that Manchester Unitedâ€™s squad doesnâ€™t need major work. Somewhere in this thicket of names there may be a combination that works, but while the departure of Matt Judge was necessary (if anything, itâ€™s surprising that he stayed beyond the departure of Woodward), it doesnâ€™t add much to the club ahead of what is likely to be an extremely busy summer. For many Manchester United supporters, the likely truth remains that the club cannot be truly reformed until the Glazer family have left. But with that looking no more likely now than at any other time over the last 17 years, supporters are left hoping against logic that this time the leopards running their clubs might finally change their spots. The post-Ferguson transition is now completing its ninth year without the clubâ€™s fortunes having substantially changed, and promises that this time things will definitely be different should probably be taken with a pinch of salt.

There should be two or three new strikers next season, itâ€™s pretty obvious.â€ CR7 in front of the Stretford End ğŸ¯ ğŸ‘ @Cristiano #MUFC | #MUNCHE pic.twitter.com/Qrnd0G1hKx â€” Manchester United (@ManUtd) April 28, 2022 On summer recruitment, he added: â€œIf you think of Manchester City and Liverpool, they brought in [players] every transfer window. â€œThey strengthened the team, they brought in players not that popular at the time when they signed and developed into the two best teams in the world. â€œI wouldnâ€™t be surprised if they play in the Champions League final in a few weeks. â€œThis shows it is possible that this can happen and it would not necessarily need three, four years in order to do that.â€ On the appointment of Ten Hag, Rangnick continued: â€œKnowing Erik will be the manager, with a good recruitment process and bringing in the right players, Iâ€™m very positive the supporters and the media will be able to see a better team and, at the end, hopefully a better position in the league. â€œThere are quite a few good examples in the league with when Jurgen Klopp came to Liverpool, Pep Guardiola to Manchester City, Thomas Tuchel came to Chelsea â€“ yes, he came in the middle of the season and inherited a top-quality squad, but you still need to win the Champions League. â€œIf you know what youâ€™re looking for, the profiles of the different positions you need, it shouldnâ€™t hopefully take too long.â€

Content_title: Saliba: â€˜I wonâ€™t be happy on Arsenalâ€™s bench, I want to startâ€™
Contents: William Saliba has once again discussed his Arsenal future, revealing his desire to â€œplay as a starterâ€ next season. They watch my matches. They tell me that we have to continue like this. â€œI havenâ€™t played much with the Gunners. The coach has made his choices, thatâ€™s life. I left on loan, I put the matches together, and I became an international. What happened to me forged a tougher mind, it is not because you have cost â‚¬30m that you are playing. I take it positively, even if there are times that you wonder. â€œFor six months I saw I was the only in the group not to play, that hurt.â€ Saliba added:â€œOf course, I canâ€™t be happy on Arsenalâ€™s bench. I want to play as a starter. Afterwards, if I enter the rotation as a substitute, itâ€™s not like being in the U23s and never being in the squad.â€ On potentially staying at Marseille, he said:â€œWeâ€™ll see after (the season). If I come back, it will be with great, great pleasure.â€

Content_title: Decision time: One loanee per club sparking a dilemma
Contents: A genuinely interminable international break plus a France debut for William Saliba was all the encouragement we needed to embark on a quest to identify one player per Premier League club currently out on loan who, for better or worse, has given his parent club a decision to makeâ€¦ Arsenal: William Saliba The Gunners have a whole gaggle of assorted players out on loan, and, despite the intriguing existence of Folarin Balogun as a striker whose Arsenal contract isnâ€™t about to expire, the most interesting loanee is once again William Saliba. He was here last year and if anything the intrigue has only grown. He has now had three hugely successful years as an Arsenal player; he just hasnâ€™t spent any of them at Arsenal. Loans at St Etienne, Nice and now Marseille have even earned him his first caps for France. Friendly caps might not seem all that big a deal, but winning a cap for France as a centre-back is just about the toughest task in the entire sport; Aymeric Laporte found it so difficult he had to become Spanish instead; Ibrahima Konate still hasnâ€™t managed it. Saliba, the man apparently surplus to requirements at Arsenal, has done it. He is understandably happy and settled at Marseille, where he plays every game, and a return to Arsenal would mean fighting for a place with Gabriel and Ben White. A lot depends on the player, but with only two years left on the five-year contract Saliba signed as a teenager, Arsenal are now very much at the point where itâ€™s time to sh*t or get off the pot.  Aston Villa: Matt Targett One of many players currently on loan â€“ along with Keinan Davis, Trezeguet, Anwar El Ghazi and Frederic Guilbert â€“ who Villa are seemingly happy to move on permanently in the summer. Targett is key, because it appears relatively straightforward to do a deal with Newcastle that suits all parties while also bringing in a reasonably sizeable transfer fee â€“ something in the order of Â£15m has been mooted â€“ to help bankroll Steven Gerrardâ€™s ambitious summer masterplan of spending Â£60m on Kalvin Phillips.  Brentford: Marcus Forss The Finland striker was in the squad for every one of Brentfordâ€™s first 23 Premier League games. But he started just one of those, getting off the bench in just six others and never for more than 30-odd minutes. He scored no goals. He went back to the Championship on loan with Hull in January and has managed just a single goal in eight appearances for the Tigers. Heâ€™s still got four years left on his Brentford contract; itâ€™s hard to see how he can be part of what will almost certainly again be a Premier League squad next year, but you can also see why heâ€™d be reluctant to leave the security of that long-term contract. Another loan?  Brighton: Kjell Scherpen The Seagulls have 13 players out on loan like some kind of petrodollar superclub. At least one of these will definitely be in the squad next season, surely â€“ striker Deniz Undav who has scored only one league goal fewer for shock Belgian league title contenders Union Saint Gilloise before and after a January sale-and-return move than his new Brighton team-mates have managed to put together in the Premier League. A more interesting one might be giant back-up keeper Scherpen, who might have been doing a more important off-field role in the first half of the season than many realised. Scherpen spent the first half of the season watching Robert Sanchez be very good indeed and is now on loan while Sanchez makes repeated bollocks of things as Brightonâ€™s season threatens to end with the sort of whimper that can have alarming knock-on effects the following year if not addressed. Even if he doesnâ€™t play a single game, Scherpen might be worth keeping around the place.  Burnley: Bailey Peacock-Farrell Weâ€™re not spoiled for choice here. Itâ€™s a third-choice goalkeeper or a fourth-choice goalkeeper. Letâ€™s go with Peacock-Farrell who is doing a decent enough job in nets for fallen giants Sheffield Wednesday as they look to clamber out of League One. Our main observation is that it doesnâ€™t matter how many games of football he plays or at what level. No matter how high his career goes we will never, ever, ever accept that Bailey Peacock-Farrell is not in fact the name of a rugby player who, after six successful years in Super League, crosses codes to join Bath or whatever and make eight appearances for England in the 15-man game.  Chelsea: Conor Gallagher There is not a single Chelsea player currently on loan at Vitesse, which is perhaps why the whole world currently seems to be desperately trying to spin itself off its axis. Itâ€™s just not right or normal, is it? Chelsea do, though, have about a million players out on loan as is customary. Now the whole global unpleasantness is of particular relevance to Chelsea, who may not in fact have any choice to make over who stays or goes or heads out on loan. They may not even exist next season. Probably they will, though. And probably they will get to decide these things. Which means a decision to make on Gallagher, who has been one of the most exciting and enjoyable players in the Premier League this season. Weâ€™re big fans of players who get to that level and still seem to visibly enjoy playing the game. Palace would, clearly, dearly love to keep him and you do get a keen sense that this is now someone who needs to be playing regularly. You canâ€™t keep him on the bench, released only for the odd runaround in a Carabao or non-vital European game. Heâ€™s tasted regular top-level football now and found it entirely to his liking. At the very least, youâ€™d think he needs to spend another year on loan playing all the football.  Crystal Palace: Luke Plange Palace only have two players currently out on loan and itâ€™s fair to say their summer thoughts might be rather more exercised by what happens next to the player they currently have on loan (see above). Anyway, the two options are a) 23-year-old American Jacob Montes who has spent the entirety of his slightly odd one-year Palace contract pulling up no trees in a pair of half-season loans in the Belgian second division and therefore b) Luke Plange, the teenager whose breakthrough at Derby convinced Palace to make a buy-and-return move in January. Palace have a bit of form for developing Football League talent into Premier League players, but youâ€™d imagine thatâ€™s probably a way off yet. A good Championship loan seems the likeliest option next season.  Everton: Moise Kean In theory, heâ€™s still in the first year of a two-year loan at Juventus with an obligation to buy at the end of it. In theory. In reality, Juventus werenâ€™t right sure a while ago and since signing Dusan Vlahovic are less convinced still about the merits of Kean who has scored just four goals in 24 Serie A games this season. All the noise suggests Juventus are looking to get out of the current arrangement and send Kean back to Goodison this summer, an outcome that we have to imagine absolutely nobody else involved wants. So whatever happens next it should be fun to see what comes of it all.  Leeds: Helder Costa In and out of the side at Valencia but has made no secret of the fact heâ€™s happier in Spain and would like to make his move permanent if everyone else is up for it. They probably will be. â€œI feel better here, I came from a not so good situation (at Leeds). But Valencia have given me the opportunity to relaunch my career and I think this is the ideal place to do that,â€ Costa toldSuper Sport last year.   Leicester City: Dennis Praet A victim of the Dreaded Metatarsal, which has kept him out of the Torino side for a couple of months at a frustrating time and appears likely now to be a season-ender. The Belgian is apparently happy in Turin and keen to stay, but the Italian side seem keen to use his injury as a means to drive down the agreed Â£12.5m option price in the current loan arrangement. Reports from the Italian end suggest Torino might favour another loan over an outright purchase but, with just two year left on his Leicester contract, youâ€™d imagine the Foxes would want something more concrete built into that. An obligation that kicks in once a set number of appearances is reached or some such thing. We donâ€™t know. Weâ€™re not contract negotiators.  Liverpool: Nathaniel Phillips Itâ€™s between Phillips and Neco Williams here. Both will still have three years left on their contracts in the summer. Both are on loan at high-flying Championship clubs. Both have obvious talent. Both face significant top-quality barriers to their first-team progression at Anfield. But itâ€™s Phillips, five years Williamsâ€™ senior, for whom the clock is more conspicuously ticking. Phillips did an admirable job in that desperate half-season for Liverpool last year when all their other centre-backs fell over, but is that situation going to present itself again? Should Bournemouth confirm promotion back to the Premier League, and that appears almost certain now given their sizeable cushion in both points and games in hand over third-placed Luton, youâ€™d imagine both player and club might be keen on a more permanent arrangement. Ticklish thing there is that longish contract, half a season of decent Premier League football behind him and apparent absence of any option in his loan contract. What would Liverpool want for him? Â£15m is a number that has been touted, and if anything youâ€™d be surprised if it was that low really.  Manchester City: Pedro Porro Just the 13 City players currently plying their trade elsewhere at the mo. Spain right-back Porro is perhaps the most interesting of those, currently in the second half of a successful two-year stint in Lisbon with Sporting that has already brought one league title and could yet bring another if a six-point gap to Porto can be overturned. Eight goals and nine assists from 65 games played predominantly at right wing-back are eye-catching numbers.  Manchester United: Donny van de Beek The arrival of a new manager in the summer means all things are a bit up in the air for Unitedâ€™s current loanees, who could suddenly find themselves far more in favour when a new man arrives. We suspect minds have been made up now, though, about Anthony Martial. Van de Beek is an intriguing one, though. Especially if Unitedâ€™s new manager does turn out to be his former Ajax gaffer Erik Ten Hag in spite of Louis van Gaalâ€™s mischief-making. Van de Beek is clearly a talent, but whether he can crack it here remains in some doubt. What is not is that he is yet to be presented with an environment to categorically prove it one way or the other. In hindsight â€“ and, if weâ€™re honest, foresight â€“ packing him off to Frank Lampardâ€™s Everton Circus might not have been a brilliant idea. Weâ€™re still really none the wiser about him.  Newcastle: Freddie Woodman If you were loaned out by Newcastle in January then really itâ€™s a pretty clear hint about where your future lies. For Woodman, who played four Premier League games at the start of the season, itâ€™s meant sitting on the bench for promotion-chasing Bournemouth as back-up to Mark Travers. It is the seventh loan of his Newcastle career, and he has one year left on his contract at St Jamesâ€™ Park. At 25, itâ€™s surely time for a permanent move to go and be first choice somewhere even if it means dropping down a tier or two.  Norwich: Todd Cantwell Like Norwich themselves, heâ€™s pretty good at getting into the Premier League but not so good at staying there. With his current loan club Bournemouth set to once again swap divisions with parent club Norwich, the logical conclusion is surely for Cantwell to go back to Norwich and complete what would be the genuinely novel achievement of a third successive promotion from the Championship. Bournemouth do, though, hold the option of making the move permanent and spoiling everything.  Southampton: Dan Nâ€™Lundulu Because there is literally nobody else other than a 23-year-old striker who scored two goals in 20 League One appearances across a pair of loans at first Lincoln and then Cheltenham before suffering a season-ending hamstring injury.  Tottenham: Bryan Gil Spurs have seven players out on loan, and with most of them the future looks pretty clear one way or the other. It would be a major surprise were Tanguy Ndombele or Giovani Lo Celso to have futures in north London, which is a shame but also probably for the best. Neither has been missed since January. Jack Clarke was Spursâ€™ attempt at a moneyball signing and itâ€™s not worked out. Cameron Carter-Vickers is likely to make his loan move to Celtic permanent. Pape Sarr, the teenage midfield sensation bought from and loaned straight back to Metz last summer, will require a decision but not a final one. The suspicion there is that heâ€™ll spend pre-season with Spurs before either being brought into the first-team squad or sent on another loan. Spurs, youâ€™d imagine, would prefer that to be to either a bottom-half Premier League club or ambitious Championship side (letâ€™s face it, it will probably be Norwich) to find out how he goes in English football. But the big decision probably regards Bryan Gil, the skilful yet painfully lightweight Spanish winger who just looked nowhere near the right sort of fit for English football. His current loan in Spain cannot tell us much but he is the one player on the Spurs list where all things are possible. This time next year he could just as easily be a Spurs first-team regular, starring for Valencia in La Liga having joined on a permanent basis, doing bits for Crystal Palace on loan or languishing at Tottenham having subsisted on the occasional Europa night which is no longer an option because Spurs have found some new and absurdly Spursy way to get knocked out. Watford: Philip Zinckernagel The Hornets look to be on to a good thing whatever happens here thanks to Zinckernagelâ€™s Nottingham Forest exploits. Heâ€™s scored five goals and laid on nine assists to help Forest into the play-off picture, but itâ€™s his eye-catching displays in Forestâ€™s fabulous FA Cup run that really make you take notice. If Watford stay up, then he has shown he can play at Premier League level. If they go down, then he has shown he can propel a Championship promotion bid. And if Watford go down and Forest go up, then they might be able to sell him for a nice price. Win, win, win. If you ignore the whole â€˜relegationâ€™ stuff, which is not a win and frankly a bit of a downer.  West Ham: Conor Coventry Because heâ€™s the only West Ham player currently out on loan. They really donâ€™t have a very big squad. The 22-year-old spent the first half of this season in the lower reaches of the Championship, making 12 appearances â€“ mainly off the bench â€“ for Peterborough, and is now in League One with MK Dons. Has just a year left on his contract at West Ham, for whom he has made three brief appearances off the bench in the League Cup.  Wolves: Adama Traore All appeared sorted when he set off to Barcelona initially on loan with a Â£29m option to make it permanent in the summer. Four assists in 10 games have gone some way to confirming the suspicion that his end-product stats might improve away from Wolves but there is yet a fly in the ointment thanks to Barcelonaâ€™s much-publicised financial problems making that Â£29m a bit steep for them. Wolves have made it clear that Traore is done at Molineux unless thereâ€™s a surprise U-turn on a new contract and even then Wolves may feel heâ€™s burned his bridges. Spurs were keen in January, but might have moved on now. Could get tricky, this.

Content_title: Man Utd legend Keane hits out at Burnley for their â€˜over the topâ€™ celebrations at Watford
Contents: Roy Keane thinks the Burnley celebrations in their 2-1 victory over Watford at the weekend were â€œslightly over the topâ€. An own goal from James Tarkowski had the Clarets 1-0 down at Vicarage Road on Saturday before late goals from Jack Cork and Josh Brownhill turned the game on its head. The comeback victory lifted them five points clear of the relegation zone before Everton beat Chelsea 1-0 on Sunday to close the gap back up to two points. Everton top Premier League winners and losers as Zaha, Arteta, Norwich and Marsch all feature Michael Jackson has now won three matches in a row as caretaker manager after Burnley sacked Sean Dyche last month but Keane thought their celebrations gotunnecessarily out of hand. Keane said on Sky Sportsâ€™ Monday Night Football: â€œBig win obviously to come from a goal down, you see the reaction there. Obviously I donâ€™t mind the manager celebrating but when I see everyone hugging and kissing I think itâ€™s just slightly over the top.â€ Presenter Dave Jones interjected: â€œThese are big results at stake arenâ€™t they?â€ Keane continued: â€œI know, I know. But there has been all season. I think Dyche wouldâ€™ve got the same results I really do but, listen, the decision is made now but thereâ€™s been a good reaction.â€ Jones then touched on Burnleyâ€™s good form and asked Jamie Carragher if that trend is continuing, to which the former Liverpool defender replied: â€œYeah, I mean, I think Roy is right, we said that last week. Sometimes a different voice, maybe a slight change, you think of the impact it has maybe had on Dwight McNeil. â€œHe did a great job, Sean Dyche, but itâ€™s something a little bit different. If you just look at the numbers, and of course weâ€™re only talking about four games, so that can be skewed because thatâ€™s such a great start. â€œBut when you see the points and the goals, thereâ€™s obviously a huge uplift there because theyâ€™ve had such a great start. But I think the thing you look at when you go down is goals conceded as well and thatâ€™s something you always looked at with Sean Dycheâ€™s team. â€œI see everyone hugging and kissing â€“ I think itâ€™s slightly over the topâ€ ğŸ˜¤ Roy Keane was NOT happy with these Burnley celebrations âŒ pic.twitter.com/dH1Zhksa7E â€” Sky Sports Premier League (@SkySportsPL) May 2, 2022 â€œBut, as I said, itâ€™s only four games. The possession is slightly up. Percentage of passes long, a slight difference, we saw that in the goal last week when we went through the goals, you know, playing through the lines a bit more. â€œAnd the 10 plus pass sequences is a real big jump. So it looks like the manager is trying to put his own stamp on it. Heâ€™s going to try and keep the good things of Sean Dyche, keeping it right, but theyâ€™re playing a bit more football. â€œSo theyâ€™ve almost changed slightly to play a bit more football, shall we sayâ€¦â€

Content_title: Keane slams Rashford after Man Utd win despite the forward staying on the bench
Contents: Roy Keane chose to criticise Marcus Rashford after Man Utd beat Brentford 3-0 on Monday night in a game the forward didnâ€™t even play in. The 24-year-old couldnâ€™t have started the season better for the Red Devils after returning from a shoulder operation with three goals in his first four matches. However, it has been downhill since then with the England international scoring just two more goals in his next 28 appearances in all competitions. Juan Mata shows Man United what theyâ€™ve wasted in beautiful Old Trafford swansong Rashford failed to get off the bench for Unitedâ€™s win over Brentford but he was still a topic of conversation for Man Utd legend Keane and his fellow Sky Sports pundit Jamie Carragher on Monday. â€œHe seems short on confidence,â€ Keane said on Sky Sportsâ€™ Monday Night Football. â€œI go back, I think heâ€™s taken his eye off the ball, with all his off the field stuff. â€œHeâ€™s got that experience, but he doesnâ€™t mix his game. Even when heâ€™s playing through the middle, I said he plays like a child [againstLiverpool]. â€œItâ€™s like heâ€™s not learnt from the game. I think heâ€™s lost the eye of the tiger and heâ€™s struggling to get it back. I think the hunger, heâ€™s got to get the hunger back and make runs like Elanga tonight. Rashford has lost that hunger which is huge for a player.â€ â€œI think heâ€™s lost the eye of the tiger!â€ ğŸ‘ğŸ¯ Roy Keane and @Carra23 discuss whether or not Marcus Rashford has â€œhit a ceilingâ€ at Manchester United ğŸ¥µ pic.twitter.com/tgqt96i5fu â€” Sky Sports Premier League (@SkySportsPL) May 2, 2022 It was only a couple of weeks ago that Keane said that Man Utd forward Rashford â€œplayed like a childâ€ in their 4-0 loss to Liverpool at Anfield. â€œJesse Lingard comes on!â€ Keane said. â€œJesse Lingard coming on to try and save Man United, Jesse Lingard should have left Man United two years ago, heâ€™s not good enough for Man United. â€œRashford played like a child up front. Okay it wasnâ€™t great service, but the one or two bits he got where he was in on goal and a poor touch. â€œDefensively, we were trying to help Maguire out here before the match, give him a little bit of PR, but the last goal, Maguireâ€™s passing and defending, not acceptable, not good enough for Man United.â€

Content_title: Rangnick praises Man Utd stars for one of their â€˜best performances in last six monthsâ€™
Contents: Ralf Rangnick praised his Manchester United players for their showing against Brentford, as it was one of their best â€œin the last six monthsâ€. Fans showed their anger at the Glazer family as their team earned themselves a 3-0 win against Brentford at Old Trafford. Bruno Fernandes, Cristiano Ronaldo and Raphael Varane netted for Man Utd on a rare night of joy for Rangnick. Manchester United are shuffling their pack, but can lost leopards change their spots? The interim managerâ€™s inability to get a consistent tune out of the squad means they are set to miss out on Champions League qualification and he admitted he was disappointed that they did not play like that more often. â€œI think tonight we probably showed one of our best performances in the last six months in possession of the ball,â€ Rangnick said. â€œWe were in control of the game in most parts. We still had a few gaps defensively but in general I was pleased with the performance we showed tonight. â€œThe season is not yet over, we have another two games to play away at Brighton and Crystal Palace. â€œWe have to divide (my time) into different parts. We had very good games, very good performance to start with and in-between, the home games against West Ham, Tottenham, away at Leeds. â€œBut what we lacked in general was just consistency. At times we had problems to score goals. We scored three today, we scored four against Leeds. â€œTo start with it was important to stabilise the team and help them to concede not that many goals, but what was lacking was consistency. â€œWe also lost quite a few important players. This also didnâ€™t help us. â€œObviously I am not completely happy with those six months. I would have expected us to qualify for Champions League. This was the goal that we had but in the end we were just not consistent enough.â€ Old Trafford said farewell to Rangnick and midfielder Nemanja Matic on Monday, with Juan Mata and Edinson Cavani also featuring before their expected summer exits. Rangnick admits he made a mistake in only handing Mata his first league start of the season on Monday â€“ a night when fellow veteran Ronaldo shone in another man-of-the-match display. The 37-year-old moved onto 18 league goals for the season and his future will be of keen interest this summer as Erik ten Hag prepares to take over. â€œThe way that he played again tonight, not only because he scored a goal, he also won the penalty, he also helped defensively tonight,â€ Rangnick said. â€œSo, why should he not be a player that could still be part of the squad and help the team? â€œThis is a question you have to ask Erik once heâ€™s here and obviously itâ€™s also important how Cristiano sees his role and his position.â€ Our last game of the season at Old Trafford. All I can do is send my thanks as always to you â€“ the United fans, you never stop supporting us even in many difficult days. In this moment lets finish the final two matches and all think positively for the new season ğŸ”´ pic.twitter.com/tgtIeb9cgg â€” David de Gea (@D_DeGea) May 2, 2022 Brentford counterpart Frank left Old Trafford frustrated not to have done better against on song United. â€œI am a bit disappointed because I think we could have performed even better, especially the first half,â€ he said. â€œActually I think we start fantastic, the first five minutes, then I felt United were more on top of the game without creating chance after chance. â€œThey had one top moment for the first goal so of course credit to them for that situation but we should have done better. â€œThey didnâ€™t really create much but I know they were a bit on the ball first half. â€œI felt that we lacked to be brave enough in the high pressure, we should be more aggressive and more cool on the ball. In spells we were too hectic. â€œBut OK, fair play to Man United. I think they hit a very high performance first half â€“ some of their better performance that I have seen so far so they did well. â€œSecond half much more the Brentford team I want to see, much more front footed. â€œWe had momentum with chances and half chances and we were definitely on top and then we make a stupid mistake for the penalty, an unnecessary mistake and that of course killed the game off I would say. â€œIf you want to win here at Old Trafford, we canâ€™t make a penalty and concede on a set piece.â€

Content_title: Juan Mata shows Man United what theyâ€™ve wasted in beautiful Old Trafford swansong
Contents: Juan Mata came, he conquered, and was forgotten about. The â€˜Wizardâ€™sâ€™ last home game for Manchester United emphasised his misspent quality. For Manchester United â€“ a club in turmoil, in need of calm heads, desperate for humility amid the arrogance, quality amid the mediocre â€“ to hand Juan Mata his first Premier League start of the season in May is an absolute nonsense. The â€˜Wizardâ€™, denied legendary status in the Premier League through Red Devil mismanagement and ill-thought-out strategy, trotted around Old Trafford on Monday, working hard, creating and â€“ perhaps most importantly â€“ caring, to give the United fans a final glimpse of what they should have seen far more of in seven-and-a-half years of wasted talent. Mata arrived at the club having won back-to-back player of the year awards with Chelsea, as one of the Premier Leagueâ€™s foremost creators. He contributed the same number of assists (32) in two-and-half seasons at Chelsea as he has in the rest of his decade-long stint in the English top flight. He very nearly surpassed his Chelsea tally on Monday. It was prime Mata. Having wandered over to the left wing from his floating No.10 role, he beautifully cushioned a volley to Bruno Fernandes on halfway, beat the offside trap to spin in behind, received the return ball, before weighting a cross perfectly into Cristiano Ronaldoâ€™s path. Had CR7 held his run by half a second, Mataâ€™s brilliance would not have been in vain. And that is, in a way, an excellent summary of his United career, as Ronaldo â€“ like his club â€“ failed to take advantage of Mataâ€™s quality. As Gary Neville referenced on commentary, the signing of Mata in January 2014 is in hindsight seen as the first of many signs of post-Fergie fuzzy-thinking. Having signed Marouane Fellaini six months before, David Moyes opted for the polar opposite as his second and final signing. Neither the Belgian brute nor the diminutive graduate of the Real Madrid academy were midfielders like any other in the preceding 20 years at Old Trafford, and have since been deemed unsuited to the hustle and bustle â€˜attack, attack, attackâ€™ of United. That speaks to perhaps the biggest problem at United in Mataâ€™s time at the club â€“ the obsession to cling to the coattails of Sir Alex Ferguson and maintain a style of football theyâ€™ve never got close to matching. Mata, and many signings since, havenâ€™t been a good fit for that United, but maybe, just maybe, itâ€™s the attempted style thatâ€™s been the greatest hindrance to the clubâ€™s progress, rather than the undoubtedly talented footballers that have failed to reach the heights they scaled at other clubs. Having said that, this victory over Brentford, Mataâ€™s only start of the season, which admittedly felt a bit like a testimonial, was as close to a Sir Alex Ferguson-like performance as any weâ€™ve seen this term. They broke quickly, with Mata, Fernandes and Ronaldo laying balls off smartly, accurately and running beyond each other. It was â€“ and this hasnâ€™t been the case for far too long â€“ entertaining football. And entertainment has been the name of Juan Mataâ€™s game in the Premier League. Heâ€™s put smiles on the faces of fans and teammates alike with unlikely assists, delicate touches and stunning long-range strikes. But most of those fond memories came in Chelsea blue, before a United career blighted by managers who failed to appreciate what he could do if they used him effectively. He leaves the Premier League with his head held high but with an irrefutable sense offrustration at what could have been.

Content_title: Tottenham eye Inter â€˜pillarâ€™ rated at â‚¬30m at the â€˜request of Conteâ€™
Contents: According to reports, Tottenham Hotspur are targeting Inter Milan defender Stefan de Vrij â€˜at the requestâ€™ of Antonio Conte. Spurs have been consistently linked with De Vrij in recent months. The former Lazio centre-back has been with Inter Milan since 2018. He has played more than 150 times for Milan over the past four seasons. Ranking Spurs players by where they sit on Conteâ€™s sh*tlist De Vrij played under Conte at Inter Milan. Together they helped the club win the Serie A title in 2020/21. Conte has been Tottenham boss since November. In January, he raided Juventus as the Londoners signedRodrigo Bentancur and Dejan Kulusevski. On De Vrij, InterLive (via Sport Witness) have suggested that Milan â€˜could lose one of their pillarsâ€™ this summer. Tottenham are interested in the Dutchman at the â€˜request of Conteâ€™. The 30-year-old would be offered a four-year deal that is worth aroundâ‚¬6.5m each season. The report adds that Inter Milan will â€˜close the dealâ€™ this summer if they receive a bid in the region ofâ‚¬25-30m for De Vrij. Elsewhere, Conte has insisted that he has the patience to see the job through at Tottenham after they were dumped out of the FA Cup at Middlesbrough. The Championship side followed up their fourth-round giant-killing of Manchester United with another Premier League scalp as teenager Josh Coburnâ€™s extra-time goal earned a deserved 1-0 win at the Riverside Stadium. â€œIn this moment Iâ€™m the last person, I donâ€™t think about myself. When I speak with my players and in my team I say that we have to think about â€˜usâ€™. Not â€˜meâ€™. â€œFor me no problem and for me there is the desire, the will, the patience to try to continue to work very hard to improve, to make this team more stable than the past, because I think this is the key that can change the situation. â€œI try every day through the work. Also sometimes to speak. For sure in this type of situation you need to find the right key to go into the mind of the players. Because itâ€™s not only sometimes a tactical problem or a technical problem. â€œSometimes you have to try to work and to push in other aspects, the mental aspects and try to stay focused and to work also on the training sessions, to keep focusing.â€

Content_title: Tottenham add two managers to their shortlist as doubts grow over Conteâ€™s future
Contents: Tottenham have added Graham Potter and Roberto Mancini to their list of possible alternatives to Mauricio Pochettino as doubts grow over Antonio Conteâ€™s future at the club, according to reports. Spurs have been improving since Conte took over in early November to replace Nuno Espirito Santo, who lost five of his last seven Premier League matches to leave the club ninth in the table. Since then, Tottenham have gradually risen up the table and now find themselves fifth, two points off fourth-placed Arsenal with five matches to play. Champions League â€˜festival of footballâ€™ plans are yet another affront to supporters Spurs have the Gunners to play in the north London derby in a fortnightâ€™s time with the match probably going a long way to deciding which of the two teams will play Champions League football next season. However, there have been rumours that Conte could jump ship this summer whatever happens in the final straight with a report insisting that the Italian has offered himself to Paris Saint-Germain. Pochettino is almost certain to leave this summer, with the manager and PSG attempting to agree a compensation package which would allow him to depart, as the French giants would have to fork outâ‚¬15m to sack him. The report on Monday claimed that there has also been â€˜contactâ€™ between Pochettino and Daniel Levy with the Tottenham chairman â€˜trying to convince the coach to return to Spursâ€™. And now the Daily Mail say that Tottenham are â€˜looking at alternativesâ€™ to Pochettino if Conte attempts to exit this summer â€˜withGraham Potterand Roberto Mancini among the names set to be consideredâ€™. It is understood that Pochettino is â€˜largely viewed as the ideal candidate to replace the Italianâ€™ but â€˜there is some opposition from within the Tottenham hierarchyâ€™ to his potential return. That â€˜resistance has led the club to explore other avenuesâ€™ with Potter and Mancini emerging as possible options. Brighton manager Potter was linked with a move to Spurs in the summer when Nuno was appointed and just before Conteâ€™s arrival in north London. The Daily Mail adds that Tottenham have â€˜long admired the work Potter has accomplished at Brighton and will be on the clubâ€™s radar if they find themselves trying to replace Conte this summerâ€™. Mancini, who is currently manager of the Italian national team, is also â€˜an optionâ€™ with Spursâ€™ managing director of football Fabio Paratici â€˜an admirerâ€™ of the former Manchester City boss. The Daily Mail adds: â€˜Itâ€™s important to stress that Tottenhamâ€™s due diligence towards the appointment of Conteâ€™s successor remains a matter of contingency preparation, with sources indicating succession planning at football clubs is completely normal. â€˜Indeed, Tottenhamâ€™s plan A is for Conte to stay in charge heading into next season â€“ and there is a feeling behind the scenes that he will not walk away.â€™

Content_title: Tottenham eye Inter â€˜pillarâ€™ rated at â‚¬30m at the â€˜request of Conteâ€™
Contents: According to reports, Tottenham Hotspur are targeting Inter Milan defender Stefan de Vrij â€˜at the requestâ€™ of Antonio Conte. Spurs have been consistently linked with De Vrij in recent months. The former Lazio centre-back has been with Inter Milan since 2018. The 30-year-old would be offered a four-year deal that is worth aroundâ‚¬6.5m each season. Elsewhere, Conte has insisted that he has the patience to see the job through at Tottenham after they were dumped out of the FA Cup at Middlesbrough. The Championship side followed up their fourth-round giant-killing of Manchester United with another Premier League scalp as teenager Josh Coburnâ€™s extra-time goal earned a deserved 1-0 win at the Riverside Stadium. â€œIn this moment Iâ€™m the last person, I donâ€™t think about myself. When I speak with my players and in my team I say that we have to think about â€˜usâ€™. Not â€˜meâ€™. â€œFor me no problem and for me there is the desire, the will, the patience to try to continue to work very hard to improve, to make this team more stable than the past, because I think this is the key that can change the situation. â€œI try every day through the work. Also sometimes to speak. For sure in this type of situation you need to find the right key to go into the mind of the players. Because itâ€™s not only sometimes a tactical problem or a technical problem. â€œSometimes you have to try to work and to push in other aspects, the mental aspects and try to stay focused and to work also on the training sessions, to keep focusing.â€

Content_title: Spurs told they are â‚¬20m short as they ready â‚¬100m double swoop
Contents: Spurs will look to make a statement this summer by bringing in winners to help Antonio Conte bring glory to the club, according to reports in Italy. Content_title: Gossip: Liverpool eye move for â€˜ragingâ€™ Real Madrid star

Content_title: Ferdinand argues â€˜brilliantâ€™ Liverpool star is the â€˜standout signingâ€™ of the 2021/22 season
Contents: Rio Ferdinand has argued that Liverpool attacker Luis Diaz is the â€œstandout signingâ€ of the 2021/22 Premier League season. When he starts, heâ€™s probably vying now to be in the first three. â€œLike, Firmino would struggle to get in there, he [Diaz] probably gets in ahead of Jota now if theyâ€™re putting their best team in a Champions League final. For those reasons, heâ€™s the standout signing of the season for me.â€ Meanwhile,Peter Crouch thinks itâ€™s between Liverpool forward Mo Salah and Manchester City midfielder Phil Foden for the PFA Player of the Year award: â€œThis year, if Manchester City win the Premier League and Champions League, you would have to pick Phil Foden or Kevin De Bruyne. Content_title: Keane claims Rangnickâ€™s decision to start â€˜magicianâ€™ reveals current Man Utd â€˜mindsetâ€™
Contents: Roy Keane thinks Man Utd are â€œgiving players a run-out for the wrong reasonsâ€ after Ralf Rangnick started Juan Mata on Monday night. The Spaniard produced a good performance for the Red Devils on Monday as they beat Brentford 3-0 at Old Trafford with goals coming from Bruno Fernandes, Cristiano Ronaldo and Raphael Varane. Mata was making his first Premier League start of the campaign with the 34-year-old starting just three of his ten appearances in all competitions this term. Manchester United are shuffling their pack, but can lost leopards change their spots? The decision by interim boss Rangnick to start Mata frustrated Man Utd legend Keane who thinks the German is â€œgiving players a run-out for the wrong reasonsâ€. â€œIâ€™m surprised. Itâ€™s his first start of the season, he obviously knows heâ€™s leaving the club. Thereâ€™s some loyalty there, giving him a run-out. â€œHe came on for 20 minutes the other night but starting a game is much different. It tells you where the mindset is. They are giving players a run-out for the wrong reasons.â€ ğŸ—£ â€œIâ€™m surprised.â€ Roy Keane says he wasnâ€™t expecting Juan Mata to start over Marcus Rashford this evening for Manchester United. pic.twitter.com/MYVJQzJ9BS â€” Football Daily (@footballdaily) May 2, 2022 But Rangnick was pleased with Mataâ€™s performance against Brentford and when asked whether he couldâ€™ve used him more often, the Man Utd boss replied:â€œYes, maybe it was the first game he played from the beginning, [but it] also had to do with the opposition in this position and in the last couple of weeks he was one of the players who showed in training how professional he is and how much he loves the game. â€œHe had moments when he played like a magician.â€ Mata is out of contract at Man Utd at the end of the season and looks almost certain that he will leave the club in the summer. On Mataâ€™s future, Rangnick added: â€œI donâ€™t know [if heâ€™s leaving]. He hasnâ€™t confirmed that but it is possible. â€œIt was an important night for players who have been here quite a long time and played well for the club.â€ Phil Jones, who has also struggled for game time in recent seasons, got on the pitch for the final 15 minutes in what is likely to be his Old Trafford farewell with Man Utd finishing the season with away trips to Brighton and Crystal Palace. â€œFor personal reasons he didnâ€™t train a lot, yesterday was the first,â€ said Rangnick of Jones. â€œHe asked me to allow him some time at home. Tonight was one of those nights I would have loved to have five subs.â€

Content_title: Keane claims Ronaldo would â€˜get 50 goalsâ€™ if he played for one of Man Utdâ€™s rivals

Imagine if he was in the Chelsea team, heâ€™d probably get 50 goals. Heâ€™s in a poor Manchester United team who arenâ€™t creating many chances for him and heâ€™s producing.â€ Keane also stated that there was a problem with the â€œattitudeâ€ of Chelsea striker Romelu Lukaku: After signing for Â£97.5m from Inter Milan in the summer transfer window, Lukaku was expected to hit the ground running at Chelsea but has managed just ten goals in 37 appearances in all competitions. He came on and again, just ambling along, not that determination to get himself a goal. As much as his fitness levels, I think his attitude doesnâ€™t seem right.â€

Content_title: Keane blasts â€˜attitudeâ€™ of Chelsea man in draw against Manchester United

He came on and again, just ambling along, not that determination to get himself a goal. As much as his fitness levels, I think his attitude doesnâ€™t seem right.â€ ğŸ—£ â€œHis attitude doesnâ€™t seem right.â€ Roy Keane on Romelu Lukakuâ€™s performance for Chelsea tonight pic.twitter.com/jd0dp8EZZp â€” Football Daily (@footballdaily) April 28, 2022 Meanwhile, Chelsea boss Thomas Tuchel was frustrated that his side didnâ€™t take all three points against Man Utd on Thursday with the Blues failing turn their chances into goals. â€œA little bit (frustrated not to win),â€ Tuchel said with a smile. â€œWe were very strong on and off the ball, very dominant on the ball, very aggressive off it. â€œA lot of ball wins, a lot of deliveries, a lot of half chances, a lot of spaces we found around the box. â€œBut unfortunately we lacked precision in the box, a bit of determination to finish it off, even very early in the match, but also throughout the whole match. â€œUnfortunately when we had it we gave it away in one minute, so it started all over again. â€œBut reaction was good again, so I am very happy with the performance because it was a huge team effort. â€œI think we showed what it needs to win on a big stage, in a big stadium, like on the focus level and the physical input level. â€œWe played with a huge team effort with a lot of quality, but unfortunately we donâ€™t have what we deserved, so we have to live with a point.â€

Content_title: â€˜Thatâ€™s just a nonsenseâ€™ â€“ Carragher blasts Man Utd over Rangnick decision
Contents: Jamie Carragher thinks itâ€™s â€œnonsenseâ€ that Ralf Rangnick will be managing Austria next season while being a consultant for Man Utd. It was confirmed late last week that he would take over as Austria boss at the end of the season but remain at Old Trafford in a part-time role. There has always been an understanding that Rangnick would move into a consultancy position at Man Utd after his period as interim manager came to an end â€“ but there was no expectation from fans that he would be doing another job at the same time. Juan Mata shows Man United what theyâ€™ve wasted in beautiful Old Trafford swansong On becoming Austria boss, Rangnick said: â€œI will take over as national team manager of Austria at the end of the season but will continue my consultancy with Manchester United. â€œIâ€™m really looking forward to playing my part in helping United become a real force again.â€ But Carragher thinks it is â€œa nonsenseâ€ that Man Utd think he will be able to fulfill his job at Old Trafford while also managing a national team. The former Liverpool defender said on Sky Sports: â€œRalf Rangnick isnâ€™t really a manager, heâ€™s a director of football, heâ€™s someone who helps the coaches or builds the club. â€œIâ€™ll be honest with you I just donâ€™t get that. I donâ€™t think you can be manager of Austria and work for Manchester United. â€œHe can work for Manchester United in that roleâ€¦well thatâ€™s wrong. That should not be happening. â€œThe manager of Austria should not be working part time for Manchester United. Thatâ€™s just a nonsense! Itâ€™s one or the other.â€ ğŸ—£ @Carra23: â€œThat is WRONG. The manager of Austria should not be working part-time for Man Utdâ€¦ that is a NONSENSEâ€ ğŸ˜¡ pic.twitter.com/Pqk3lUndWL â€” Sky Sports Premier League (@SkySportsPL) May 2, 2022 Carragher hasnâ€™t been the only pundit to be critical of the idea with former Man Utd defender Gary Neville insisting there will be a â€œconflictâ€ between the two jobs. Neville told Sky Sports: â€œThe Austrian national team has pride, great country and some great players so heâ€™ll have to watch players all week then heâ€™s going to go and coach them for two weeks in September, October, November and March. So youâ€™re saying to yourself whatâ€™s happening with the Manchester United consultancy advice? â€œWhere is the priority? Thereâ€™s a conflict there.â€ Neville added: â€œI donâ€™t see that. I donâ€™t see how that can work, youâ€™re a national team manager and Iâ€™ve worked under a national team manager, that national team manager has got to present week in, week out, Saturday, Wednesday, Saturday, Tuesday and he canâ€™t be here at Old Trafford every week watching an Austrian player play. â€œI canâ€™t see how thatâ€™s going to work, if itâ€™s something thatâ€™s true. Maybe (itâ€™s a compromise) but itâ€™s messy, Manchester United canâ€™t afford at this moment to have distractions, canâ€™t afford at this moment in time to have a poor communications plan around the idea that Ralf Rangnickâ€™s our football consultant but heâ€™s seen watching German football three times a month then going coaching the Austrian team two times a month. â€œThatâ€™s not going to work because people are going to say â€˜hang on, whoâ€™s in the directorâ€™s box? Whatâ€™s Darren Fletcher doing? Whatâ€™s John Murtough doing? Whatâ€™s Ralf Rangnick doing wherever heâ€™s watching an Austrian player? â€œI donâ€™t think they can afford that at this moment in time. Laser-focused, clear lines, people staying in their lines understanding what their roles are and actually communicating that to a fan base, this is a real change, this is different than it has been for the last 10 years.â€

Content_title: Carragher backs â€˜fantasticâ€™ Liverpool youngster to become â€˜first choiceâ€™ next season â€“ â€˜let him playâ€™
Contents: Jamie Carragher has backed Liverpool defender Ibrahima Konate to become the clubâ€™s first-choice centre-back alongside Virgil van Dijk. Konate signed for Liverpool last summer from RB Leipzig. The Red paid around Â£36m to bring him to the Premier League. The centre-back has been a bit-part player this term.
